At the Kingsville Cattle Auction in central Missouri, hundreds of bulls, steers and heifers jostle in pens in a huge barn, waiting to be herded onto the sale floor.
Ronald Bibey (ph) is a small cattle producer, a cow calf man with 50 head of blank Angus cattle on his ranch in Deepwater, Missouri.
Like many ranchers, he's not in favor of a national mandatory system for registering and tracking cattle.

The big thing, I think, that most cattlemen fear is the fact that information they gather will be used against us in some way, and also that the cost of running a system would be passed on down to us, which, personally, I don't feel that we can bear a whole lot more cost.

The cost is $1.00 or $2.00 per animal for radio transmitter ear tags, thousands of dollars more for feed lots and meatpackers, who would need new equipment to track and maintain records of the animals they receive.
Ronald Bibey says ranchers also worry about just who else would have access to a national database.
We think, for instance, if the meatpackers could use us by knowing how many cattle there's actually in the system at any given time, that's one thing.
Another way it could be used against us would be by the environmental people.

That opposition from cattle producers is one reason why Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns announced last summer that any national database for animals would be run by industry groups, not by the government.
Many cattlemen want any tracking system to be voluntary, and for now, the USDA is going along.
Kansas Livestock Commissioner, George Teagarden, though, says he believes a national I.D.
system won't work unless it is mandatory, covering the entire cattle industry.
As for concerns that a national database might help meatpackers control cattle prices:
In reality, those packers already know that information.
Yes, we will have that kind of information, and if you do some research and put one and one together, you probably will come up with two, but these databases will not be open to the general public.
Teagarden insists that any database would only be for tracking disease and open only to public health officials.
If such a system were in place now, officials say they already would have a lot of information about the third U.S.
case of mad cow disease -- where else the cow lived, where it might have contracted the disease and which other animals should be tested.
USDA officials are working to trace the animal's history, but that's a process that's not likely to be quick or easy.

The last time the USDA tried to trace the herd of a cow with a disease, it took months, and, in the end, because of a lack of records, agriculture officials were unable to locate 20 herd mates of the animal that had mad cow disease.
